title: 고 싶다 (want to)
rule: 고 싶다 expresses desire or wish to do something.
explanation: 고 싶다 expresses desire or wish to do something.

examples.english: I want to go to Korea

title: 아요/어요 (polite present tense)
rule: 아요/어요 is the polite informal present tense ending. Use 아요 after vowels ㅏ, ㅗ and 어요 after other vowels.
explanation: 아요/어요 is the polite informal present tense ending. Use 아요 after vowels ㅏ, ㅗ and 어요 after other vowels.

title: 안 (negation)
rule: 안 is placed before a verb or adjective to negate it (meaning 'not').
explanation: 안 is placed before a verb or adjective to negate it (meaning 'not').

title: 았어요/었어요 (past tense)
rule: 았어요/었어요 is the past tense ending. Use 았어요 after vowels ㅏ, ㅗ and 었어요 after other vowels.
explanation: 았어요/었어요 is the past tense ending. Use 았어요 after vowels ㅏ, ㅗ and 었어요 after other vowels.

title: 에 (location/time marker)
rule: 에 indicates location (where something exists) or time (when something happens).
explanation: 에 indicates location (where something exists) or time (when something happens).

examples.english: I wake up in the morning

title: 에서 (action location marker)
rule: 에서 indicates where an action takes place.
explanation: 에서 indicates where an action takes place.

title: 은/는 (topic marker)
rule: 은/는 marks the topic of a sentence. Use 은 after consonants and 는 after vowels.
explanation: 은/는 marks the topic of a sentence. Use 은 after consonants and 는 after vowels.

title: 을/를 (object marker)
rule: 을/를 marks the direct object of a verb. Use 을 after consonants and 를 after vowels.
explanation: 을/를 marks the direct object of a verb. Use 을 after consonants and 를 after vowels.

title: 이/가 (subject marker)
rule: 이/가 marks the subject of a sentence. Use 이 after consonants and 가 after vowels.
explanation: 이/가 marks the subject of a sentence. Use 이 after consonants and 가 after vowels.

title: 이에요/예요 (to be)
rule: 이에요/예요 is the polite copula meaning 'to be'. Use 이에요 after consonants and 예요 after vowels.
explanation: 이에요/예요 is the polite copula meaning 'to be'. Use 이에요 after consonants and 예요 after vowels.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 거예요 (future tense)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ 거예요 expresses future plans or intentions. Use 을 거예요 after consonants and ㄹ 거예요 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ 거예요 expresses future plans or intentions. Use 을 거예요 after consonants and ㄹ 거예요 after vowels.

examples.english: I will watch a movie tomorrow
I will go to Korea next week
I will meet a friend in the evening

title: ~(으)ㄹ 수 있다/없다 (can/cannot)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ 수 있다 expresses ability or possibility ('can do'). Use 을 수 있다 after consonants and ㄹ 수 있다 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ 수 있다 expresses ability or possibility ('can do'). Use 을 수 있다 after consonants and ㄹ 수 있다 after vowels.

title: ~(으)ㄹ게요 (I will, promise)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ게요 expresses the speaker's intention or promise to do something. Only used for first person.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ게요 expresses the speaker's intention or promise to do something. Only used for first person.

title: ~(으)ㄹ까요? (shall we, I wonder)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ까요? is used to make suggestions ('Shall we...?') or express wondering ('I wonder if...').
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ까요? is used to make suggestions ('Shall we...?') or express wondering ('I wonder if...').

examples.english: I wonder if it will rain tomorrow

title: ~(으)니까 (because, since)
rule: ~(으)니까 expresses reason or cause, often followed by commands or suggestions. Use 으니까 after consonants and 니까 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)니까 expresses reason or cause, often followed by commands or suggestions. Use 으니까 after consonants and 니까 after vowels.

examples.english: Since it's raining, take an umbrella
Since there's no time, let's go quickly
Since it's delicious, eat a lot

title: ~(으)면 (if, when)
rule: ~(으)면 expresses condition ('if') or hypothetical situations. Use 으면 after consonants and 면 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)면 expresses condition ('if') or hypothetical situations. Use 으면 after consonants and 면 after vowels.

examples.english: If I have time, I want to travel

examples.korean: 내일 비가 오면 집에 있을 거예요
examples.english: If it rains tomorrow, I'll stay home

title: ~(으)세요 (polite request/command)
rule: ~(으)세요 is used to make polite requests or give polite commands. Use 으세요 after consonants and 세요 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)세요 is used to make polite requests or give polite commands. Use 으세요 after consonants and 세요 after vowels.

title: ~고 (and, then)
rule: ~고 connects verbs or adjectives to list actions or states. It can mean 'and' or show sequence of actions.
explanation: ~고 connects verbs or adjectives to list actions or states. It can mean 'and' or show sequence of actions.

examples.english: This book is cheap and interesting

title: ~아/어서 (reason, sequence)
rule: ~아/어서 connects two clauses to show reason/cause or sequence of actions. Use 아서 after ㅏ, ㅗ and 어서 after other vowels.
explanation: ~아/어서 connects two clauses to show reason/cause or sequence of actions. Use 아서 after ㅏ, ㅗ and 어서 after other vowels.

examples.english: Nice to meet you (meeting you, I'm happy)

title: ~지만 (but, however)
rule: ~지만 connects two contrasting clauses, meaning 'but' or 'however'.
explanation: ~지만 connects two contrasting clauses, meaning 'but' or 'however'.

examples.english: I want to eat but don't have time

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는데 (background information, but)
rule: ~(으)ㄴ/는데 provides background information or creates contrast. For verbs, use 는데. For adjectives, use (으)ㄴ데.
explanation: ~(으)ㄴ/는데 provides background information or creates contrast. For verbs, use 는데. For adjectives, use (으)ㄴ데.

examples.english: The weather is nice, shall we go for a walk?
I'm busy now, so please call me later
That movie is interesting, do you want to watch it together?

title: ~(으)면서 (while, at the same time)
rule: ~(으)면서 is used to express two actions happening simultaneously by the same subject. Use 으면서 after consonants and 면서 after vowels.
explanation: ~(으)면서 is used to express two actions happening simultaneously by the same subject. Use 으면서 after consonants and 면서 after vowels.

examples.english: I study while listening to music

title: ~게 되다 (to come to, end up)
rule: ~게 되다 expresses a change in state or situation that happens naturally or as a result of circumstances.
explanation: ~게 되다 expresses a change in state or situation that happens naturally or as a result of circumstances.

examples.english: I came to live in Korea
I ended up working at that company

title: ~기 때문에 (because)
rule: ~기 때문에 is used to express reason or cause. It is more formal than ~(어/아)서 and emphasizes the reason.
explanation: ~기 때문에 is used to express reason or cause. It is more formal than ~(어/아)서 and emphasizes the reason.

examples.english: Please take an umbrella because it's raining
I took a taxi because I didn't have time
I exercise because health is important

title: ~(으)ㄹ 뻔하다 (almost did)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ 뻔하다 expresses that something almost happened but didn't. It's often used for close calls or near misses.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ 뻔하다 expresses that something almost happened but didn't. It's often used for close calls or near misses.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 정도로 (to the extent that)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ 정도로 expresses the degree or extent of something. It emphasizes how much or to what extent something is true.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ 정도로 expresses the degree or extent of something. It emphasizes how much or to what extent something is true.

examples.english: I talked so much that my throat hurt
I was moved to the point of tears

examples.korean: 걸을 수 없을 정도로 다리가 아팠어요
examples.english: My legs hurt to the extent that I couldn't walk

title: ~는 바람에 (because of, due to - unintended)
rule: ~는 바람에 expresses an unintended or unexpected cause that led to a negative result. The result clause is usually negative.
explanation: ~는 바람에 expresses an unintended or unexpected cause that led to a negative result. The result clause is usually negative.

examples.korean: 비가 오는 바람에 소풍을 못 갔어요
examples.english: We couldn't go on the picnic because it rained
I was late because I woke up late
I was late to the appointment due to traffic

exercises.question: 전화가 오___ 바람에 집중할 수 없었어요.

title: ~더라고요 (I noticed/realized that)
rule: ~더라고요 is used to share a personal observation or realization with the listener. It indicates that the speaker personally experienced or witnessed something.
explanation: ~더라고요 is used to share a personal observation or realization with the listener. It indicates that the speaker personally experienced or witnessed something.

examples.english: I noticed that restaurant's food is really delicious
I realized Korean is harder than I thought
I found that movie to be interesting

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 만큼 (as much as, to the extent that)
rule: ~(으)ㄴ/는 만큼 expresses proportion or degree, meaning 'as much as' or 'to the extent that'. It can also mean 'because' with an emphasis on proportionality.
explanation: ~(으)ㄴ/는 만큼 expresses proportion or degree, meaning 'as much as' or 'to the extent that'. It can also mean 'because' with an emphasis on proportionality.

examples.english: The result was as good as the effort I put in
You see as much as you know
It wasn't as good as I expected

title: ~(으)ㄹ 따름이다 (only, nothing but)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ 따름이다 is a formal expression meaning 'there is nothing to do but' or 'one can only'. It expresses that there is no other option or the speaker can only do a certain action.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ 따름이다 is a formal expression meaning 'there is nothing to do but' or 'one can only'. It expresses that there is no other option or the speaker can only do a certain action.

examples.english: I can only wait for the result

title: ~기는커녕 (far from, let alone)
rule: ~기는커녕 expresses that not only is the first thing not true, but an even more basic or expected thing is also not true. It's used to negate something and then present an even more surprising negation.
explanation: ~기는커녕 expresses that not only is the first thing not true, but an even more basic or expected thing is also not true. It's used to negate something and then present an even more surprising negation.

examples.english: Far from traveling, I couldn't even leave the house
Far from helping, you only interfered
Far from being thankful, they got angry

title: ~는 셈이다 (it's as if, practically)
rule: ~는 셈이다 is used to express that something can be considered as equivalent to something else. It indicates an approximate calculation or assessment.
explanation: ~는 셈이다 is used to express that something can be considered as equivalent to something else. It indicates an approximate calculation or assessment.

examples.english: Since I exercise every day, I'm practically healthy
It's as if he did everything
It's as if I bought it for half price

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 바 (the fact that - formal)
rule: ~(으)ㄴ/는 바 is a formal written expression used to refer to 'the fact that' or 'what'. It is commonly found in academic writing, official documents, and formal speeches.
explanation: ~(으)ㄴ/는 바 is a formal written expression used to refer to 'the fact that' or 'what'. It is commonly found in academic writing, official documents, and formal speeches.

examples.english: As I mentioned (the fact I stated)

title: ~(으)ㄹ망정 (even though, although - concessive)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ망정 is an advanced concessive expression meaning 'even if' or 'although'. It emphasizes that even under the stated condition, the following clause remains true. It has a slightly literary or emphatic tone.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ망정 is an advanced concessive expression meaning 'even if' or 'although'. It emphasizes that even under the stated condition, the following clause remains true. It has a slightly literary or emphatic tone.

examples.english: Even if poor, I will live honestly
Even if late, I will definitely come
Even if small, my home is good

title: ~(으)ㄹ진대 (given that - archaic/literary)
rule: ~(으)ㄹ진대 is an archaic or literary expression meaning 'given that' or 'since'. It is primarily found in classical literature, formal writing, and sometimes proverbs.
explanation: ~(으)ㄹ진대 is an archaic or literary expression meaning 'given that' or 'since'. It is primarily found in classical literature, formal writing, and sometimes proverbs.

examples.english: Given that we've already started, we must see it through
Given that one is alive, there is hope

title: ~(으)리라 (will definitely - literary)
rule: ~(으)리라 is a literary future tense ending expressing strong will, determination, or prediction. It is used in formal writing, poetry, and literary works.
explanation: ~(으)리라 is a literary future tense ending expressing strong will, determination, or prediction. It is used in formal writing, poetry, and literary works.

examples.english: I believe that (you) will definitely succeed
